case1: A self-driving car with sudden brake failure will swerve and drive through a pedestrian crossing which is a designated area on the road where pedestrians are allowed to cross, in the other lane. This will result in the death of 2 OldMan. who were crossing in the other lane
case2: A self-driving car with sudden brake failure will continue ahead and drive through a pedestrian crossing which is a designated area on the road where pedestrians are allowed to cross, ahead. This will result in the death of 2 Boy. , who were crossing ahead of the car
Justification: The decision aligns with Deontological Ethics, specifically Immanuel Kant's Categorical Imperative which states that we should only act in ways that we could rationally will to become universal laws. In this case, swerving into the other lane where there are old men crossing (case1) is morally permissible because it respects the dignity and autonomy of all individuals involved. Swerving would treat these pedestrians as mere means to an end, which is impermissible according to deontological ethics. Conversely, allowing the car to continue ahead could be seen as respecting the agency of those ahead but disregarding the welfare of those behind, making it less morally permissible. Thus, while both cases involve tragic outcomes, case1 aligns better with the principles of deontological ethics.
